title: Adult animation in the United States
text:
In the United States, before the enforcement of the <a href="Hays%20Code">Hays Code</a>, some cartoon shorts contained humor that was aimed at adult audience members rather than children. Following the introduction of the <a href="Motion%20Picture%20Association%20of%20America%20film%20rating%20system">Motion Picture Association of America film rating system</a>, <a href="independent%20animation">independent animation</a> producers attempted to establish an alternative to mainstream animation. Initially, few animation studios in the United States attempted to produce animation for adult audiences, but later examples of <a href="adult%20animation">animation produced for adults</a> would gain mainstream attention and success. Adult animation in the United States includes shows with superhero, sci-fi, and fantasy elements. Some of the most prominent animations with these mature themes include "<a href="The%20Simpsons">The Simpsons</a>", "<a href="Bojack%20Horseman">Bojack Horseman</a>", "<a href="South%20Park">South Park</a>", "<a href="Futurama">Futurama</a>", and "<a href="Archer%20%282009%20TV%20series%29">Archer</a>", along with other adult animated television series, feature films, and animation in other forms which helped the genre expand over the years.
Pre-Code animation.
The earliest cartoon series were based upon popular <a href="comic%20strip">comic strip</a>s, and were directed at family audiences. Most animation produced during the <a href="silent%20film">silent film</a> era was not intended to be shown to any specific age group, but occasionally contained humor that was directed at adult audience members, including risqué jokes. Writer Michael Tisserand argued that all animations were "adult swims in the early days of American animation," with shapes which were hand-drawn, frolicking and not behaving "correctly" before audience members who "reacted with shock at this new life they were witnessing." Some scholars, like Jason Mittel, stated that the assumed audience of these early cartoons, particularly "<a href="Looney%20Tunes">Looney Tunes</a>", has alternated from their initial unspecific audience, to children, and back to general audiences as "classics". The earliest known instance of censorship in animation occurred when the censorship board of Pennsylvania requested that references to <a href="Rum-running">bootlegging</a> be removed from <a href="Walt%20Disney">Walt Disney</a>'s 1925 short "<a href="Alice%20Comedies">Alice Solves a Puzzle</a>". One of the earliest animated <a href="pornographic%20films">pornographic films</a> was "<a href="Eveready%20Harton%20in%20Buried%20Treasure">Eveready Harton in Buried Treasure</a>", produced circa 1928. It has often been suggested that the film was produced for a private party in honor of <a href="Winsor%20McCay">Winsor McCay</a>. According to Karl F. Cohen's 1998 book, "Forbidden Animation: Censored Cartoons and Blacklisted Animators in America", rumor held that that the film was developed in <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a> years after it was completed, because no lab in New York City would process the film. When a print was screened in San Francisco in the late 1970s, the program notes attributed the animation to <a href="George%20Stallings">George Stallings</a>, George Canata, Rudy Zamora, Sr. and <a href="Walter%20Lantz">Walter Lantz</a>.
The <a href="Motion%20Picture%20Association%20of%20America">Motion Picture Association of America</a>, then known as the Motion Pictures Producers and Distributors Association, was established in 1922 as the result of public objection to adult content in films, and a series of guidelines were established, suggesting content that should not be portrayed in films. Until the <a href="Hays%20Code">Hays Code</a> was enforced, many animated shorts featured suggestive content, including <a href="sexual%20innuendo">sexual innuendo</a>, references to alcohol and drug use, and mild <a href="profanity">profanity</a>. In the 1933 short "<a href="Bosko%27s%20Picture%20Show">Bosko's Picture Show</a>", <a href="Bosko">Bosko</a> appears to use profanity, although it has also been suggested that the character is saying "<a href="fox">fox</a>", or even "<a href="mug">mug</a>". Apart from this, in the 1920s and 1930s, <a href="X%20rating%23United%20States">X-rated</a> cartoons were produced and shown, building upon the "small non-theatrical industry" which had developed "around pornographic films before WWI."
 The latter cartoons came at time when the U.S. military began to commission animated films to train recruits. This morphed into the U.S. Army's <a href="First%20Motion%20Picture%20Unit">First Motion Picture Unit</a>, which existed from 1942 to 1945 located at <a href="Hal%20Roach%20Studios">Hal Roach Studios</a> in <a href="Culver%20City%2C%20California">Culver City, California</a>. The unit included filmmakers like <a href="Frank%20Capra">Frank Capra</a>, "<a href="Looney%20Tunes">Looney Tunes</a>" creator <a href="Rudolf%20Ising">Rudolf Ising</a>, animator <a href="Frank%20Thomas%20%28animator%29">Frank Thomas</a>, and cartoonist <a href="Dr.%20Seuss">Dr. Seuss</a>, and it produced hundreds of animated "training films on a continuous schedule." Animation was integral in these films, helping pilots fly airplanes, soldiers learn the fine points of <a href="military%20camouflage">military camouflage</a>, or train others how to correctly use hand-held weapons.
The <a href="Betty%20Boop">Betty Boop</a> series was known for its use of jokes that would eventually be considered taboo following the enforcement of the Hays Code, including the use of nudity. Betty Boop was initially drawn as a dog, and cast as the girlfriend of another Fleischer character, <a href="Bimbo%20%28Fleischer%29">Bimbo</a>. Betty was redesigned as a human, but the series continued to suggest a love relationship between the two that went further than the normal relationship between humans and their pets. The short "<a href="Is%20My%20Palm%20Read">Is My Palm Read</a>" contains a scene in which Betty is shown as a child between the ages of four and five, bathing in the nude. In the 1970s, this scene was shown out of context in performances by <a href="Oingo%20Boingo">The Mystic Knights of the Oingo Boingo</a>. Concert audiences were not aware that Betty was supposed to be a baby in the sequence.
Another short, "<a href="Betty%20Boop%27s%20Bamboo%20Isle">Bamboo Isle</a>", contains a sequence in which Betty dances the <a href="hula">hula</a> topless, wearing only a <a href="lei%20%28garland%29">lei</a> over her breasts and a <a href="grass%20skirt">grass skirt</a>. According to animator <a href="Shamus%20Culhane">Shamus Culhane</a>, <a href="Fleischer%20Studios">Fleischer Studios</a> and <a href="Paramount%20Pictures">Paramount Pictures</a> were shocked by the sequence, but because it was a major sequence, it could not be cut out of the film. Culhane also states that he does not remember any instance in which the film was censored. Betty's hula animation was reused for a cameo appearance with <a href="Popeye%20the%20Sailor">Popeye the Sailor</a> in his self-titled animated debut short <a href="Popeye%20the%20Sailor%20%28film%29">of the same name</a>.
Following the enforcement of the Hays Code, Betty's clothing was redesigned, and all future shorts portrayed her with a longer dress which did not emphasize her physique and sexuality. Shorts produced following the enforcement of the Hays Code were also less surreal in nature, and Betty was portrayed as a rational adult.
After the Hays Code.
By 1968, the Hays Office had been eliminated, and the former guidelines were replaced by the <a href="Motion%20Picture%20Association%20of%20America%20film%20rating%20system">Motion Picture Association of America film rating system</a>. The lifting of the Code meant that animated features from other countries could be distributed without censorship, and that censorship would not be required for American productions. Some underground cartoon features from the late 1960s were also aimed at an adult audience, such as "<a href="Bambi%20Meets%20Godzilla">Bambi Meets Godzilla</a>" (1968), and the anti-war films "<a href="Escalation%20%28animated%20short%29">Escalation</a>" (1968), and "<a href="Mickey%20Mouse%20in%20Vietnam">Mickey Mouse in Vietnam</a>" (1969). "Escalation" in particular is interesting because it was made by Disney animator <a href="Ward%20Kimball">Ward Kimball</a>, independently from the <a href="Walt%20Disney%20Animation%20Studios">Disney Studios</a>. Film producer John Magnuson completed an animated short based upon an audio recording of a comedy routine by <a href="Lenny%20Bruce">Lenny Bruce</a> titled "<a href="Thank%20You%20Mask%20Man">Thank You Mask Man</a>" (1971), in which <a href="The%20Lone%20Ranger">The Lone Ranger</a> shocks the residents of the town he saves when he tells them that he wants to have sex with <a href="Tonto">Tonto</a>. The short was made by <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a>-based company Imagination, Inc. and directed by Jeff Hale, a former member of the <a href="National%20Film%20Board%20of%20Canada">National Film Board of Canada</a>. The film was scheduled to premiere on the opening night of "<a href="Z%20%281969%20film%29">Z</a>", as a supplement preceding the main feature, but was not shown. According to a former staff member of the festival, Magnuson ran up the aisle and shouted, "They crucified Lenny when he was alive and now that he is dead they are screwing him again!" The festival's director told Magnuson that the producer of "Z" did not want any short shown that night. Rumors suggested that the wife of one of the festival's financiers hated Bruce, and threatened to withdraw her husband's money if the short was screened. "Thank You Mask Man" was later shown in art house screenings, and gained a following, but screenings did not perform well enough financially for Magnuson to profit from the film.
Animated series.
In the 1990s and 2000s.
"<a href="Aeon%20Flux">Aeon Flux</a>", which aired from 1991 to 1995, was American <a href="avant-garde">avant-garde</a> <a href="science%20fiction">science fiction</a> <a href="Animated%20series">animated television series</a> that aired on <a href="MTV">MTV</a>. Liana Satenstein called it "cutting edge, bizarrely sexy, and certainly not for daytime television," which has cult-following, while <a href="Peter%20Chung">Peter Chung</a>, the director of the animated show, stated he was inspired by the "very naked images of the late <a href="Helmut%20Newton">Helmut Newton</a>." Dramatic series such as "<a href="Aeon%20Flux">Aeon Flux</a>" and "<a href="Invasion%20America">Invasion America</a>" are less common, and still rarely successful. Discussions involving a series based upon Trey Parker and <a href="Matt%20Stone">Matt Stone</a>'s video Christmas card, "<a href="The%20Spirit%20of%20Christmas%20%28short%20film%29">The Spirit of Christmas</a>", led <a href="HBO">HBO</a> to contact Ralph Bakshi in order to produce an animated series targeted specifically toward adults. Bakshi enlisted a team of writers, including his son, Preston, to develop "Spicy Detective", later renamed "<a href="Spicy%20City">Spicy City</a>", an <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a> set in a <a href="Film%20noir">noir-ish</a>, technology-driven future. Each episode featuring a different story narrated by a female host named Raven, voiced by <a href="Michelle%20Phillips">Michelle Phillips</a>. The series premiered in July 1997, unexpectedly beating "<a href="South%20Park">South Park</a>" to television by over a month and becoming the first "adults only" cartoon series. Although critical reaction was mixed and largely unfavorable, "Spicy City" received acceptable ratings. A second season was approved, but the network wanted to fire Bakshi's writing team and hire professional <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a> screenwriters. When Bakshi refused to cooperate with the network, the series was canceled. FOX's "<a href="The%20PJs">The PJs</a>", airing from 1999 to 2001, featured <a href="Eddie%20Murphy">Eddie Murphy</a> and his "stop motion animated story of life within the projects," with the name an abbreviation for "the projects." This show lasted three seasons, but later was cancelled in 2001, fading into obscurity.
"" ran on Cartoon Network from 1994 to 2001, then on <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a> from 2001 to 2004, followed by being on <a href="GameTap">GameTap</a> from 2006 to 2008. The first two seasons of this adult animated parody <a href="talk%20show">talk show</a> were presented as a serious talk show with subdued jokes, while the later seasons relied more on <a href="surrealism">surrealism</a>, <a href="non%20sequitur%20%28literary%20device%29">non-sequitur</a>, and tabloid. Not only was it said to be first original series fully produced by <a href="Cartoon%20Network">Cartoon Network</a>, but it had two <a href="Spin-off%20%28media%29">spinoff</a> series in the form of "<a href="Cartoon%20Planet">Cartoon Planet</a>" and "<a href="The%20Brak%20Show">The Brak Show</a>", while inspiring series such as "<a href="Sealab%202021">Sealab 2021</a>"; "<a href="Aqua%20Teen%20Hunger%20Force">Aqua Teen Hunger Force</a>"; "<a href="Harvey%20Birdman%2C%20Attorney%20at%20Law">Harvey Birdman, Attorney at Law</a>"; "<a href="Perfect%20Hair%20Forever">Perfect Hair Forever</a>"; and "<a href="The%20Eric%20Andre%20Show">The Eric Andre Show</a>". The series was described as "zany superhero spoof" which established a formula used on <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a> and elsewhere, with a specific "randomness and raunchy sense of humor."
Beginning in the 2000s, "<a href="Celebrity%20Deathmatch">Celebrity Deathmatch</a>" was an American <a href="stop-motion">stop-motion</a> <a href="Clay%20animation">claymated</a> series created by <a href="Eric%20Fogel">Eric Fogel</a> for <a href="MTV">MTV</a>. which depicts various <a href="celebrities">celebrities</a> engaging in highly stylized <a href="professional%20wrestling">professional wrestling</a> matches. As such, it is known for its large amount of gory violence, including combatants employing different abilities and weapons to deliver particularly brutal attacks, resulting in exaggerated physical injuries. Two <a href="television%20pilot">television pilot</a>s were broadcast on MTV in January 1998, but the series proper premiered on May 14, 1998, and ended on June 6, 2002, airing for 75 episodes. Then, for a brief period during that year, reruns of the series aired on broadcast network <a href="UPN">UPN</a>, the series came back for two seasons between 2006 and 2007. Later, in April 2015, MTV2 announced a reboot of the series, but in November 2016, Fogel stated via Twitter that MTV did not pick up the pilot to series. As a whole, the series was called an "off-the-wall show" which has goofy and edgy comedy, becoming a "uniquely appealing romp."
In September 2001, <a href="Time%20Warner">Time Warner</a> established <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a> as a programming block on Cartoon Network, aimed for an adult audience, in contrast to the different demographic targeted for Cartoon Network, which some said was the beginning of "great changes" in the "world of adult animated series" for the next twenty years. Its schedule currently includes original programs such as "<a href="Rick%20and%20Morty">Rick and Morty</a>" and "<a href="The%20Venture%20Bros.">The Venture Bros.</a>", as well as more "experimental" shows such as "<a href="Aqua%20Teen%20Hunger%20Force">Aqua Teen Hunger Force</a> and" "<a href="Squidbillies">Squidbillies</a>". Some said that the programming block was inspired by shows like "<a href="Beavis%20and%20Butt-Head">Beavis and Butt-Head</a>" and "<a href="Aeon%20Flux">Aeon Flux</a>"." The programming block also marked the return of "<a href="Space%20Ghost%20Coast%20to%20Coast">Space Ghost Coast to Coast</a>", which ran on <a href="Cartoon%20Network">Cartoon Network</a> from 1994 to 2001, Adult Swim from 2001 to 2004, and <a href="GameTap">GameTap</a> from 2006 to 2008. In the case of "The Venture Bros", it became a fan favorite due to its callbacks, "fast-paced dialogue" and commentaries about the "dark realities behind American television icons" while "Rick and Morty" had "tightly structured, high concept adventures." The creation of Adult Swim, posed in 2000 by Mike Lazzo and Michael Ouweleen after a <a href="Cartoon%20Network">Cartoon Network</a> team saw how many adults were watching their channel, originally confused executives who thought that adults don't watch cartoons, leading them to begin with a small number of shows made of the cheap and aimed at young men. This effort was successful, with the programming block developing "a cult following." Later, adult animation got a boost with the revival of Samurai Jack in 2017 on <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a>, followed by "<a href="Primal%20%28TV%20series%29">Primal</a>" and "" in later years. In 2006, R. Thomas Ulmstead reported that while adult animations aired on <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a>, <a href="Anime%20Network">Anime Network</a>, and on the website of <a href="Comedy%20Central">Comedy Central</a>, this animation continued to push "television's content envelope beyond anything seen on basic cable," as is the video game business.
From 2000 to 2005, "<a href="Sealab%202021">Sealab 2021</a>", an American adult animated television series, aired first on <a href="Cartoon%20Network">Cartoon Network</a> before the official inception of the <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a> block on September 2, 2001, with the final episode airing on April 24, 2005. "Sealab 2021" is one of the four original <a href="Williams%20Street">Williams Street</a> series that premiered in 2000 before Adult Swim officially launched, the others being "<a href="Aqua%20Teen%20Hunger%20Force">Aqua Teen Hunger Force</a>", "<a href="The%20Brak%20Show">The Brak Show</a>" and "<a href="Harvey%20Birdman%2C%20Attorney%20at%20Law">Harvey Birdman, Attorney at Law</a>". Much like Adult Swim's "<a href="Space%20Ghost%20Coast%20to%20Coast">Space Ghost Coast to Coast</a>", the animation used stock footage from a 1970s <a href="Hanna-Barbera">Hanna-Barbera</a> cartoon, in this case the short-lived, <a href="Natural%20environment">environmentally</a>-themed "<a href="Sealab%202020">Sealab 2020</a>", along with original animation. The show was a satirical parody of both the original "Sealab" series and the general conventions of the 1970s animated children's series. While there was initial resistance from several of the original series' creators to the reuse of their characters, production moved forward on the series. "Sealab 2021" was produced by <a href="70/30%20Productions">70/30 Productions</a>, which eventually closed on January 9, 2009. The series was noted as an "underwater cartoon comedy" that fans of <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a> should revisit, saying there is a "unique charm and historical significance" to the show, as it was said to "pioneer the modern-day trend of goofy and occasionally lude satirical animation." From 2006 to 2008, "<a href="Frisky%20Dingo">Frisky Dingo</a>", an animation created by those who had worked on "<a href="Sealab%202021">Sealab 2021</a>", aired on <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a>. It was described as having nuanced and original animation which is "rife with crazy moments," while having various "epic moments and funny action film parodies."
"<a href="Sit%20Down%2C%20Shut%20Up%20%282009%20TV%20series%29">Sit Down, Shut Up</a>" was cancelled after its first season in 2009. In this series, Andrew LeGustambos is a flamboyant and bisexual drama teacher whose last name in Spanish roughly translates to "he likes both", a reference to his sexual orientation. He is in love with Larry Littlejunk and Miracle Grohe, with whom he hopes to get into a relationship should they become a couple. In 2011, "<a href="Good%20Vibes%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">Good Vibes</a>" aired on MTV, but was cancelled after one season. This <a href="Surfing">surfer</a> <a href="comedy">comedy</a> was described by some critics as "criminally underappreciated," while equipped with engaging plotlines, hilarious gags, vibrant animation, and lamented for only lasting one season. From 2014 to 2015, <a href="Stone%20Quackers">Stone Quackers</a> aired on <a href="FXX">FXX</a> as part of their <a href="Animation%20Domination%20High-Def">Animation Domination High-Def</a> block. While only running for 12 episodes, critics described it as having colorful episodes, having hilarious and memorable characters, and said it effectively mixes "black comedy with genuine heartfelt moments," making it one of the "most fun and inventive adult cartoons" of the 2010s.
In the 2010s.
In 2017, <a href="Rick%20Moranis">Rick Moranis</a> pitched a cartoon about him as a demon slayer titled "The Gatekeeper" but <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a> passed on the idea. Even though the idea had been developed, even with the drawing of concept art, Adult Swim cancelled the project, concerned about their "target audiences." In September 2020, a <a href="ScreenRant">ScreenRant</a> writer, Lucas Bermudez, called on Adult Swim to consider the idea once again. The cancellation of Moranis's show came at a time that <a href="SYFY">SYFY</a>, then owned by <a href="NBCUniversal%20Television%20and%20Streaming">NBC Broadcasting and Sports</a>, was rebranded, with Chris McCumber, who had become SYFY's president, adding "adult animation, live pop-culture coverage, podcasts and other programming" to the network.
In 2019, <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> ordered 10 episodes of an adult animation produced by <a href="Fremulon">Fremulon</a> and <a href="3%20Arts%20Entertainment">3 Arts Entertainment</a> titled "<a href="Q-Force%20%28TV%20series%29">Q-Force</a>", which focuses on LGBTQ superspies, as part of <a href="List%20of%20Netflix%20original%20programming%23Adult%20animation%202">its original programming</a>, with its release date currently unknown. "<a href="Love%2C%20Death%20%26amp%3B%20Robots">Love, Death & Robots</a>" began streaming on Netflix in March 2019. VFX editor and supervisor Brad Minnich described it as "an R-rated, adult animated feature" with various different styles, and that he descovered that there are various animators, and other creatives, who don't get a chance to work on this type of subject matter. Other reviewers said that the show is an "adult animation" with animators deciding this means "tits and profanity...rather than, well, stories fit for adults."
In December 2019, Reuben Baron, an animation critic for "<a href="Comic%20Book%20Resources">CBR</a>" pointed out the recent negative toward adult animation, with people calling it "being ugly, immature and generally inferior to cartoons aimed at children," saying that while they make some sense as criticisms of a "lot of the cheaper Adult Swim series," they are exceptions, due to the wide "variety of high-quality adult animation options." He argued that the common criticism of such animation, even a few years before could be true as adult cartoons were comedic while dramatic or action storylines were in children's animation. He stated that apart from the CG animation in "", shows like "<a href="Seis%20Manos">Seis Manos</a>", "<a href="Love%2C%20Death%20and%20Robots">Love, Death and Robots</a>", "Primal", "Undone", "Outsiders", and "Harley Quinn" are well animated, challenging the stereotype they are "ugly." Reuben further stated that adult animation, however, has to increase the "representation of women's perspectives" like in <a href="All-ages%20animation">children's animation</a>, while noting that "Big Mouth" has become "the de facto punching bag for complaints about adult animation" even though it has a female co-creator named Jennifer Flackett and it "tries hard to be socially conscious." He also noted that "old standbys" like "Bob's Burgers", "Rick and Morty" and "Bojack Horseman" continue to hold weight, even as he noted the failings of "Family Guy" and "South Park", while believing that dismissal of adult cartoons is due to "defensiveness from fans of kids' cartoons." He concluded by looking forward to "existing adult animation" to come in 2020, while stating that we might be "in an adult animation Renaissance."
From 2020 to Present.
In January 2020, <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> and an animation studio, <a href="Titmouse%2C%20Inc.">Titmouse, Inc.</a>, came to an agreement to produce "multiple original adult animated series" the names of which are yet to be announced. The next month, it was reported that <a href="YouTube">YouTube</a> agreed to create "a system of defining criteria for children." Some criticized this as the AI they implemented viewed animated content as for children, saying this is an incorrect assumption, pointing to shows like "<a href="Family%20Guy">Family Guy</a>", "<a href="The%20Simpsons">The Simpsons</a>", "<a href="South%20Park">South Park</a>", "<a href="Bob%27s%20Burgers">Bob's Burgers</a>", "<a href="Big%20Mouth%20%28TV%20series%29">Big Mouth</a>", "<a href="Bojack%20Horseman">Bojack Horseman</a>", and "<a href="Happy%20Tree%20Friends">Happy Tree Friends</a>". She further stated that animation can cover various subjects and should be taken seriously in the ability to create a wide array of content than be labeled as "for children."
In March 2020, a <a href="white%20paper">white paper</a> written by John Evershed, stated that adult animation is growing thanks to streaming platforms, a continued loss of cable viewers, animations going beyond comedy, shows which are not comedies are "easier to export," and the shortage of talent in this area even with "the sheer demand for adult animation." Dan Sarto <a href="Animation%20World%20Network">Animation World Network</a> also wrote about the report, stating that non-comedy adult-focused animation "appears to be a growing part of their current and future animation development and programming plans." In his report, Evershed wrote that before 2020, adult animation was either irreverent, were family sitcoms, or <a href="anime">anime</a>, but this changed by 2020. Evershed highlighted companies like <a href="Titmouse%2C%20Inc.">Titmouse, Inc.</a>, Williams Street, and Bento Box producing adult animations, while customers are willing to pay for various streaming services. He also differented between <a href="all-ages%20animation">all-ages animation</a> and adult animation, and noted the adult animation strategy of major streaming services, specifically pointing out that <a href="Disney%2B">Disney+</a> eschewed adult animated content.
In April 2020, it was reported that Syfy was expanding its 90-minute <a href="TZGZ">TZGZ</a> animation block with three new series and two pilots, specifically "Hell Den", "<a href="Wild%20Life%20%28TV%20series%29">Wild Life</a>", "Dr. Havoc’s Diary", "<a href="Plutonians">Plutonians</a>", and "Psycho Psalms". In June, this expanded when Syfy ordered the animated series, "Devil May Care". Carole Horst "<a href="Variety%20%28magazine%29">Variety</a>" also reported that animated featured outside the U.S. have a history of "Telling difficult stories" and that adult animation is increasing across the world, while noting that creators of such animation are embracing it and thinking what they can do with their ability to do effective storytelling, some even calling it "liberating" or a perfect medium to talk about social issues. This included "Santa Inc." showrunner Alexandra Rushfield, Shadowmachine co-founders Alex Bulkley and Corey Campodonico, "<a href="Crossing%20Swords">Crossing Swords</a>" creators John Harvatine IV and Tom Root, "Fireheart" creator Laurent Zeitoun, and Trioscope studios founders L.C. Crowley and Brandon Barr. Horst also stated that as those distributing content and streaming platforms are taking chances with these animations, it is a "golden age of animation as creatives discover the freedom of tooning up." Later in November 2020, <a href="Animation%20World%20Network">Animation World Network</a> interviewed the showrunner of "Hell Den", coming into its second season, Neil Garguilo. He stated that the adult animation block, <a href="TZGZ">TZGZ</a>, encouraged them to go "as far as we’d like in terms of the comedy" and stated that they did not face any pushback.
In July 2020, critics talked about the "boom" in adult animation. Some highlighted new series like "<a href="BoJack%20Horseman">BoJack Horseman</a>", "<a href="Big%20Mouth%20%28TV%20series%29">Big Mouth</a>", "<a href="Solar%20Opposites">Solar Opposites</a>", "<a href="Disenchantment%20%28TV%20series%29">Disenchantment</a>", "<a href="F%20is%20for%20Family">F is for Family</a>", "<a href="Final%20Space">Final Space</a>", "<a href="Duncanville%20%28TV%20series%29">Duncanville</a>", and "<a href="Harley%20Quinn%20%28TV%20series%29">Harley Quinn</a>", adding that these series have been in the making for years due to the length of the development process. Animated feature films.
Ralph Bakshi.
By the late-1960s, animator <a href="Ralph%20Bakshi">Ralph Bakshi</a> felt that he could not continue to produce the same kind of animation as he had in the past. Bakshi was quoted in a 1971 article for the "<a href="Los%20Angeles%20Times">Los Angeles Times</a>" as saying that the idea of "grown men sitting in cubicles drawing butterflies floating over a field of flowers, while American planes are dropping bombs in <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> and kids are marching in the streets, is ludicrous." With producer <a href="Steve%20Krantz">Steve Krantz</a>, Bakshi founded his own studio, Bakshi Productions, establishing the studio as an alternative to mainstream animation by producing animation his own way and accelerating the advancement of female and minority animators. He also paid his employees a higher salary than any other studio at that time.
In 1969, <a href="Ralph%27s%20Spot">Ralph's Spot</a> was founded as a division of Bakshi Productions to produce commercials for <a href="Coca-Cola">Coca-Cola</a> and "<a href="Max%2C%20the%202000-Year-Old%20Mouse">Max, the 2000-Year-Old Mouse</a>", a series of educational shorts paid for by <a href="Encyclop%C3%A6dia%20Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a>. However, Bakshi was uninterested in the kind of animation he was producing, and wanted to produce something personal. Bakshi soon developed "<a href="Heavy%20Traffic">Heavy Traffic</a>", a tale of inner-city street life. However, Krantz told Bakshi that studio executives would be unwilling to fund the film because of its content and Bakshi's lack of film experience. While browsing the East Side Book Store on <a href="St.%20Mark%27s%20Place%20%28Manhattan%29">St. Mark's Place</a>, Bakshi came across a copy of <a href="Robert%20Crumb">Robert Crumb</a>'s "<a href="Fritz%20the%20Cat">Fritz the Cat</a>". Impressed by Crumb's sharp satire, Bakshi purchased the book and suggested to Krantz that it would work as a film.
"<a href="Fritz%20the%20Cat%20%28film%29">Fritz the Cat</a>" was the first animated film to receive an <a href="X-rated">X rating</a> from the MPAA, and the highest grossing independent animated film of all time. While the film is widely noted in its innovation for featuring content that had not been portrayed in American animation before, such as explicit sexuality and violence, the film also offered commercial potential for alternative and independent animated films in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, as the film offered a mature, satirical portrayal of the 1960s, including portrayal of drug use, political tension and race relations. Bakshi has been credited for playing an important role in establishing animation as a medium where any story can be told, rather than a medium for children. As a result of the acceptance of Bakshi's features, the director suggested that "<a href="War%20and%20Peace">War and Peace</a>" could be produced as an animated film.
Because of the perception that "Fritz the Cat" was pornographic, Krantz attempted to appeal the film's rating, but the MPAA refused to hear the appeal. Praise from "<a href="Rolling%20Stone">Rolling Stone</a>" and "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>", and the film's acceptance into the <a href="1972%20Cannes%20Film%20Festival">1972 Cannes Film Festival</a> cleared up previous misconceptions. Bakshi then simultaneously directed a number of animated films, starting with "<a href="Heavy%20Traffic">Heavy Traffic</a>". Krantz was nervous about showing too much nudity and sexual content, and had several versions of some scenes animated. Thanks to "Heavy Traffic", Bakshi became the first person in the animation industry since <a href="Walt%20Disney">Walt Disney</a> to have two financially successful films released back-to-back. Although the film was critically praised, it was banned by the film censorship board in the province of <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a>, Canada when it was originally released.
Bakshi's next film, "<a href="Coonskin%20%28film%29">Coonskin</a>" was produced by <a href="Albert%20S.%20Ruddy">Albert S. Ruddy</a>. The film, culled from Bakshi's interest in African-American history in America, was an attack on racism and racist stereotypes. Bakshi hired several African-American animators to work on "Coonskin" and another feature, "<a href="Hey%20Good%20Lookin%27%20%28film%29">Hey Good Lookin'</a>", including Brenda Banks, the first African-American female animator. After the release was stalled by protests from the <a href="Congress%20of%20Racial%20Equality">Congress of Racial Equality</a>, which accused both the film and Bakshi himself of being racist, the film was given <a href="limited%20release">limited distribution</a>, advertised as an <a href="exploitation%20film">exploitation film</a>, and soon disappeared from theaters.
Bakshi avoided controversy by producing <a href="fantasy%20film">fantasy film</a>s, including "<a href="Wizards%20%28film%29">Wizards</a>", "<a href="The%20Lord%20of%20the%20Rings%20%281978%20film%29">The Lord of the Rings</a>" and "<a href="Fire%20and%20Ice%20%281983%20film%29">Fire and Ice</a>". Bakshi did not produce another animated feature film after the 1992 release of "<a href="Cool%20World">Cool World</a>". In 2015, after securing funding through a <a href="Kickstarter">Kickstarter</a> campaign, he released the short film "<a href="Last%20Days%20of%20Coney%20Island">Last Days of Coney Island</a>" on the internet.

Festivals.
In 1988, <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a> exhibitor <a href="Expanded%20Cinema">Expanded Cinema</a> screened a compilation of adult-oriented animated shorts under the title "Outrageous Animation". Advertising the package as containing "the wildest cartoons ever", the screenings contained shorts produced outside the United States, as well as independently produced American shorts. Reviews of the festival were mixed. "<a href="San%20Francisco%20Chronicle">San Francisco Chronicle</a>" writer <a href="Mick%20LaSalle">Mick LaSalle</a> hated almost everything screened at the festival, with the exception of <a href="Bill%20Plympton">Bill Plympton</a>'s "<a href="One%20of%20Those%20Days">One of Those Days</a>". In "<a href="The%20San%20Francisco%20Examiner">The San Francisco Examiner</a>", David Armstrong gave the show a three-star review and described the films screened as having "some of the rude vitality of the great old Warner Bros. cartoons —and a good deal of the sexual explicitness denied those old favorites from a more cautious age."
In 1990, Mellow Manor Productions began screening films under the title "<a href="Spike%20and%20Mike%27s%20Sick%20and%20Twisted%20Festival%20of%20Animation">Spike and Mike's Sick and Twisted Festival of Animation</a>". Founders Craig "Spike" Decker and Mike Gribble promoted their festival by handing out flyers on the streets rather than with traditional promotional techniques. In 1991, Decker and Gribble screened their first "All Sick and Twisted Festival of Animation", promising "wild and zany films that could never be shown to our 'normal audience'". The festival screened newer independent shorts, as well as older shorts such as "Bambi Meets Godzilla", and "Thank You Mask Man". Although the festival promoted works by animators who would later gain mainstream success, such as <a href="Bill%20Plympton">Bill Plympton</a>, <a href="Mike%20Judge">Mike Judge</a>, <a href="Trey%20Parker">Trey Parker</a> and <a href="Don%20Hertzfeldt">Don Hertzfeldt</a>, many reviewers dismissed the bulk of the programming as <a href="shock%20value">shock value</a>.
In 2003, Judge and Hertzfeldt created a new touring festival of animation marketed towards adults and college students. <a href="The%20Animation%20Show">The Animation Show</a> brought animated shorts into more North American theaters than any previous commercial festival.
Growing interest in young adult animation.
For years, <a href="Young%20adult%20fiction">young adult</a> animation, known as YA animation for short, has been discussed by executives and creators, especially those in the United States. In 2000, Tom Freston, the CEO of <a href="MTV">MTV</a>, said that his network was at the cutting-edge of young adult animation. A few years later, a H2VEntertainment, a <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>-based animation company, financed three animated features aimed "at the teen and young adult market" which would premiere in spring 2004.
Fast forward to the 2010s, when more critics and companies would begin talking about young adult animation. In 2015, one critic stated that the executives in the <a href="animation%20industry">animation industry</a> in the United States weren't on board with the idea of young adult animation, leading some to do <a href="Indiegogo">Indiegogo</a> projects instead. Others wrote about animation for young adults among <a href="anime">anime</a> in Japan, a theme which continued in later years. A few years later, in 2019, one reviewer argued that "<a href="Adventure%20Time">Adventure Time</a>" pushed the "parameters of young-adult animation." The same year, <a href="41%20Entertainment">41 Entertainment</a> partnered with <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> to produce "animation for young adults" like a reboot of "", scheduled to be released in fall 2021. Also, <a href="Line%20Webtoon">Webtoon</a> partnered with <a href="The%20Jim%20Henson%20Company">The Jim Henson Company</a> to develop Rachel Smythe's webcomic, "<a href="Lore%20Olympus">Lore Olympus</a>" into a young adult animated series. The latter webcomic is one of the world's most popular comics
and garners some of the highest views of any comic on Webtoon itself. The Jim Henson Company has produced animations like "<a href="Word%20Party">Word Party</a>", "<a href="Splash%20and%20Bubbles">Splash and Bubbles</a>", "<a href="Dot.">Dot.</a>", "<a href="The%20Doozers">The Doozers</a>", and "<a href="Dinosaur%20Train">Dinosaur Train</a>", among <a href="The%20Jim%20Henson%20Company%23Television">other TV shows</a>.
The same month, <a href="Crunchyroll">Crunchyroll</a> and Webtoon announced a partnership to produce animated works of LINE Webtoon's catalog, with both creating a team to tackle distribution, licensing, and retail of the series produced from the partnership. Around the same time, some HBO executives claimed that <a href="South%20Park">South Park</a> would anchor their "young adult animation offering," along with a slate of <a href="Adult%20Swim">Adult Swim</a> series, anime programming from <a href="Crunchyroll">Crunchyroll</a>, and "exclusive U.S. streaming rights" to most of the films produced by <a href="Studio%20Ghibli">Studio Ghibli</a>.
In 2020, young adult animation came to the forefront once more. <a href="HBO%20Max">HBO Max</a> was said to have a lot of material "oriented towards young adults" in contrast with <a href="Disney%2B">Disney+</a>. At the same time, some reviewers described "<a href="The%20Dragon%20Prince">The Dragon Prince</a>" as a young adult animation and the <a href="National%20Academy%20of%20Television%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">NATAS</a> gave out various <a href="Emmy%20Award">Emmys</a> for young adult programs, like "<a href="Rapunzel%27s%20Tangled%20Adventure">Tangled</a>", differentiating them from <a href="All-ages%20animation">children's animation</a> and <a href="preschool%20animation">preschool animation</a>. 2020 was the first year that NATAS gave a Daytime Emmy for young adult programs, which includes shows "targeting a tween and teen audience." Then, on October 22, Radford "Rad" Sechrist, the series creator of "<a href="Kipo%20and%20the%20Age%20of%20Wonderbeasts">Kipo and the Age of Wonderbeasts</a>" floated the idea of a streaming service creating "a dedicated YA animation division," stating that it would have shows like "Kipo", along with a "dedicated YA team to target that audience." He also suggested that this could be a way for smaller streaming services to distinguish themselves, saying that while animators are trying to target kids with their <a href="all-ages%20animation">all-ages animation</a>, that "young adult is wide open," calling it an "untapped market." Matt Braly, creator of "<a href="Amphibia%20%28TV%20series%29">Amphibia</a>", and Owen Dennis, the creator of "<a href="Infinity%20Train">Infinity Train</a>", concurred. Braly stated that a lot of "YA animated content" is deemed too old for the 6-11 age group, but "too young for "adult" animation," calling it a "purgatory" while Dennis argued that it would help creators so they would not be boxed in by executives. <a href="Giancarlo%20Volpe">Giancarlo Volpe</a>, an <a href="Italian-American">Italian-American</a> <a href="animator">animator</a>, director, producer and comic creator also agreed with Sechrist's suggestion.
